data.text: Strong Tires for a Heavy-Loaded Touring Bicycle

Bike tires! After an above average number of flat tires (and trying different tires and going tubeless...) on my tour across the US, I'm wondering what tires (tested and proven on long multi-day tours in a heavily loaded bike) you would recommend? I was thinking about going back to tubes and installing the Schwalbe marathon Plus tires. At the same time, my tour ends with the GAP and C&O which has gravel and I'd like to have confident handling on the gravel. Is there a tire that has similar puncture protection as the schwalbe and is a gravel tire? Also, I haven't had a flat with my tubeless front tire (terravail gravel tire), would it be a good idea to keep the front one as it is and just change the rear tire? Thanks!

i rode the GAP and C&O last year on some 20 x 1.5" road tires on my folding bike. The paths are mostly smooth and groomed with just a few potholes on the C&O. About any bike/tire combo will do fine there
data.author: Kent Robinson

data.text: I agree. The canals surfaces are easy to ride on about any tire.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: My first tour I rode with Continential GatorSkins about 5,200 miles across the USA without a single flat. End up getting about 6K miles out of each tire before they need changed. Have had the occassional flat since then but mostly due to overuse of the tire. Wont use anything else.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: same here!
data.author: Ed Weingarten

data.text: I've settled on tubeless tires in the 700x40 range. I haven't had a flat touring since swithing in 2019. Though I never had many flats with tubes either so I preferred mid weight tires over the overbuilt hard touring standards. Just my preference
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: which tires do you use?
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: Donelly USH, Specialized Sawtooth, and Teravail Rampart. Also toured a Summer on wtb byway 659bx47. Good experience with all of them. The sawtooth are probably the most robust of tye group
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: You are not likely to get punctures on gravel compared to the side of a busy highway which has lots of concentrated debris
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: Schwalbe Marathon Plus Tour are by far and away the most robust tyres!
data.author: Allan Lees

data.text: I use Schwalbe Marathon on my touring bike and love them. On road, gravel, dirt, rocks, even sand recently. Never had a puncture (knock on wood) since I installed them about 3 years ago (maybe 6,000 km so far).
data.author: Paolo Marchiori

data.text: I'm thinking of running a tube in the rear and staying tubeless up front. So sick of flatting the rear and spraying sealant everywhere.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: Indeed! I'm leaning towards that side too. I've had to plug my Teravail Rutland rear tires 3-5 times in the past week and a half. So maybe it's because they need replacing, but I have just put 2200km / 1370 miles on them, 98% road. I've been told mixed things by bike mechanics; some say after a single puncture and using a tubeless plug you should replace the tire when you can - an expensive idea when touring.
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: wouldn't that give you more flats?
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: I'm not sure. I just flatted my tubeless on a trip and it sprayed all of the sealant out. I put a tube in and it was fine for the rest of the trip. I've just been having so many flats this year. Putting sealant in during a tour is not very practical so it just seems like tubes are easier if your out on the road. I'll probably put it back to tubeless but Part of me I'd just sick and tired of the sealant spraying around and getting my bags all mucked up. It's just getting old. tubes just seem easier at the moment. I think most of my flats these days are from nails or glass or something that's going to flat whether it's tubed or tubeless so why have sealant spray all over...?
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: try a Tannus Armour Tubeless insert in your existing rear tubeless setup - they make a "gravel" size now! All the benefits of tubeless with even fewer flats, smoother ride.
data.author: Ken Bradford

data.text: GAP and C&O are mostly hard pack so Marathon‚Äôs are recommended
data.author: Don Ferguson

data.text: I used Bontrager AW3 hard case lite tires (w/tubes) on my recent TransAm attempt ..no issues for the 1000 miles that I managed to complete and roads were heavy with debris thru OR and ID.
data.author: Ed Wallig

data.text: I also used Bontrager for a 600 mile NL/Belgium (cobbles) tour without any issues- tubes, no flats, heavy load- great tires!
data.author: Kathy Swords

data.text: Marathon+. I don't get flats anymore. Change both tires. The cost is not that high to alleviate flat concerns.
data.author: Brent Irvine

data.text: yeah the downsize is the weight/rolling resistance/being slower and handling on gravel roads / versatility
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: Less about the actual tires and more about the sealant. Tubes or tubeless make sure you‚Äôre using adequate sealant at all times.
data.author: Russ McCoy

data.text: What is adequate sealant? I've had it installed by three different bike shops here in the US. Three different sealants recommended by each of them because they've had "excellent performance" which whatever brand they're suggesting.
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: Agreed. Also, wider tires. I very rarely ride skinny road tires anymore. Mostly coz I hate pavement.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: I use Stans. Orange seal also has a good rep. Have you determined what is causing all the flats??
data.author: Russ McCoy

data.text: I've been using Continental Touring tires for 8 years. Maybe 3 flats in that entire time. Lucky?
data.author: Brian Sculac

data.text: Yes. The American classic Kimberlites. They are very very reliable with excellent puncture protection fast and smooth rolling and something like $35 a tire. As far as gravel...since there are vastly different grades of gravel, and having completed the whole GAP/C&O on 23c Conti 4000s, I feel 100% confident these will handle everything on that segment of the ride along with providing quite a bit more grip and stability. I have them on my bike as 700x50. There is also the Udden, a bit slower on the road but probably faster on gravel. There is also the Donnelly X'Plor MSO which I can honestly say is a beast of a tire in terms of versatility. It's a pretty beefy tire but rolls along nicely on the road and gravel. The Udden is very similar in specs and tread pattern.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text:
After taking these on Pacific Coast Highway and Route 66 (rear tire lasted PCH and 1800 mi of Rt66 before succumbing to a slash - coulda kept using it, it still had plenty of life but had the spare and the cut was one of those ‚Äúmatter of when not if‚Äù things). Rode mostly asphalt, but of varying condition, and never had issues with dirt roads or the occasional trail explore. While I understand the legendary status of the Marathon‚Äôs, these foot the bill in taking the exploration off road. https://www.panaracerusa.com/products/gravelkingss7b
GravelKing SS Plus+ Folding Gravel Tire
panaracerusa.com
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: Marathon are the best
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text:
I swapped from Marathon Plus to Mondials about 4 years ago and they‚Äôve been great. The number of punctures is about the same but the grip is much better and they feel more comfortable when loaded up. Another advantage for us is that they do a folding version so, with 2 bikes fitted with 4 x Mondial 700c x 40 we carry a single spare. And have been doing so for 4 years ü§£ü§£ü§£ https://bikehikesafari.com/best-bicycle-touring-tires/
Best Bicycle Touring Tires [2022] BikeHikeSafari
bikehikesafari.com
data.author: Mark Litherland

data.text: I'm running the mondials DD right now on tour in Alaska. I had 3 different puncher ,one rainy day from the wires from radial tires
data.author: Edward Gregory

data.text: - never had anything like that. These have about 7-8000km on them and have a lot more wear yet.
data.author: Mark Litherland

data.text: The Marathon Plus are perfect for the GAP/C&O.
data.author: David Hothem

data.text: My girlfriend and I are one the road for 1 year. We had on the way really tough routes and I can recommend you Schwalbe Mondial!
data.author: Jan Ngo

data.text: Continental 4 season
data.author: Carole Smith

data.text: I use the Schwalbe Marathon Plus MTB. It has been as flat resistant as the regular Marathon Plus but is 2.1" wide and has an off-road tread. It's perfect for gravel or dirt trails, and also does surprisingly well on the road
data.author: Stewart Houck

data.text: Continental Gatorskin. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
data.author: Ralph Vickrey

data.text: My question is why so many flats? I have not had a flat with many more miles and much tougher surfaces in several years. I have used everything from the Marathon plus (did not like it in any way) to cheap tires I picked up in a motorcycle repair shop in Peru. I switched to tubeless 2 years ago and will remain with this setup. Much smoother ride, better handling, and no flats. Keep your tires in good condition, replacing them when you see the wear marks gone. If you are using tubes, use good quality ones.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: i used schwalbe marathon plus and didnt get a single flat all the way across the country
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: What is your objective here? If it is puncture resistance, that generally rules out tubes. A properly maintained tubeless system is much less likely to puncture, so the question I would ask is for tubeless tyres unlikely to puncture. Tubolito City tour tyre. 1y puncture resistance.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: I disagree. A properly maintained tubeless system is not less likely to puncture. I've had brand new tires set up tubeless by a bikeshop on tubeless compatible everything and has failed multiple times before reaching 1000 miles. 5 out of 6 punctures required a tubeless plug (which worked). Also had other bikeshops check the system if everything was looking okay and add / change sealant. All in all bad experience.
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: , what tire and set up? Mt biker here for bikepacking, 1 Flat in 8 years.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: If I were you, I‚Äôd figure out why I was getting so many flats, rather than going tubeless on a tour. Is there something still in your tire? Are you not avoiding road hazards as well as you could be?
data.author: William Griggs

data.text: WTB Horizon 47c. No flat for 1500 kms with tubes. And they have seen lots of sharp big sized gravel.
data.author: Mats Aadde

data.text: Rather than looking for a ‚Äúsolution‚Äù to make flats ‚Äújust go away‚Äù be so prepared to mend a puncture that you look forward to puncture mending opportunities. You may be surprised how few flats you get. I only got 2 flats across the USA.
data.author: Bravos Louis

data.text: huh? Having 7-10 flats before reaching the halfway point across the US and instead of figuring out a more robust system I should've just been looking forward to the flats instead?
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: We‚Äôve run WTB Ventures and Specialized Pathfinder Gravel tubeless for 4,000km without puncher or issue and recently switched to the Panaracer Gravel King SS about 700km ago and are really happy with their performance. Much better rolling resistance and great performance off-road as well.
data.author: Jason Gard

data.text: wow, how come no punctures? Would you say it's luck? Where were you touring? In an area with little highway debris? Or do you keep most weight upfront instead of the rear wheel? What sealant do you use? You haven't had to plug a single puncture with any of the mentioned tires? I'm really surprised.
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: also running 50mm Panaracer GravelKings tubeless (on tour in Alaska) but the SK+ version for max puncture resistance.
data.author: Bill Burke

data.text:
not sure why we‚Äôve been so lucky. I also fitted them myself after watching a few pros on YouTube and have been blown away by how reliable our tubless have been. I‚Äôd never go back to tubes after the past two summers touring. We rode some fairly rough sections as we toured from Trento in Italy‚Äôs north to Rome doing the Via degli Dei and Via Francigena both are amazing old pilgrim routes. This summer it‚Äôs been another 2k without issue. We‚Äôve seriously had zero punctures and are using this Vittoria sealant https://www.vittoria.com/ww/en/bike-accessories/tyre-sealant/universal-tubeless-tire-sealant I put 100ml in each tyre and shake it well and bounce it. We also use good valves that have a larger seating area. I saw that this is key to them holding pressure as it‚Äôs the valve that mostly leaks. Nice Bill sounds like a good ride! I tried to order the SS+ but they were out in the 650‚Äôs. That will be the next tyre for sure but so far I‚Äôve given these some stick and they‚Äôve come through solid. Just did a part gravel 550km ride carrying an extra 15kg of gear without issues. The best surprise is how fast these things are so nice to ride them and they‚Äôre so fat and grippy!
Universal Tubeless Tire Sealant | Liquid Latex: anti-puncture gel for road bikes and mtb | Vittoria
vittoria.com
data.author: Jason Gard

data.text: Teravail Washburn
data.author: Toma≈æ ≈†vagan

data.text: Regardless of what tires, use tire liners and puncture resistance tubes. Yes they will add a bit more weight but will greatly reduce your chance of a flat. I used them on a 4000 mile ride (unloaded) heavy recumbent and did not have a flat.
data.author: Cliff Multanen

data.text: Mondials
data.author: Steven Bowie

data.text: Schwalbe Marathon Plus, cheap ass tubes. 1100 miles around Florida - 0 flats DC to Seattle via Cand O and Gap - 5 flats Anchorage to Fort Lauderdale - 7 flats.
data.author: Dave Sner

data.text: I just did the southern tier with a larger load than you. 3400 miles on schwalbe marathon plus tires. One set, never rotated. Zero flats. Front tire looks almost like new. Back tire 50% wear.
data.author: Doug Arntson

data.text: The ‚Äúheavily loaded‚Äù part of your question would push me to stick with the Schwalbe. I did the GAP and C&O (also The Great Divide) with Marathon Mondails front and rear and had no issue with the gravel/mud I encountered. My bike was about 75 lbs loaded.
data.author: Rob Robertson

data.text:
This is the tire you need: https://www.schwalbe.com/nl/tour-reader/marathon-almotion

data.author: Frank Van Dessel

data.text: It is remarkable versatile and I‚Äôve never had a flat. Even on the rockiest ‚Äúroads‚Äù in the south of Italy where roads are notoriously bad (even the off roads üôÉ)
data.author: Frank Van Dessel

data.text: Just finished the southern tier. My riding partner had Schwalbe marathon Plus - zero flats, even after taking bike off road in goat head areas. I rode with Terravail gravel tires and got two flats one night from goat heads. I pumped up both tires and the Stans did its job. I eventually replaced rear tire when it lost a chunk of tread rolling over glass. Front tire is still holding air 2500+ miles later. I did learn the rubber in graves tires works better on graves vs a mix of road and gravel.
data.author: John Boyle

data.text: I use cheap Walmart tubes, you‚Äôll find green slime sealant in the same isle. I only use it in the front. And a set of the same slime brand puncture resistant liners, right by the sealant. I don‚Äôt use slime in the back because the liner will slip if any of the slime gets out onto it but the front doesn‚Äôt have so much load and seals up nice. I seldom have to deal with flats anymore, and when I do it‚Äôs usually just one fine piece of blowout wire
data.author: Nesta Skychild

data.text: What‚Äôs the reason for the flats? All punctures or harder to diagnose? If you are really heavily loaded, make sure you are putting in adequate pressure - higher than unloaded generally and probably higher end of what‚Äôs recommended for the tire. I‚Äôve been riding tubeless 700c x 50 which have been great. I‚Äôd like to go a bit smaller, but struggled to find availability during Covid.
data.author: Kevin Voll

data.text: Schwalbe Marathon....and make sure you have the right pressure.

data.text: Either using a pump with a air pressure gauge ( don't know the correct English word) or from experience by using the thumb and applying pressure. Tubeless tyres need less pressure, but I have no experience from these.
data.author: H√•kan Frennesson

data.text: I don't use tubless tires, neither a pump with a gauge, do I think I'm gonna have to use my thumb üòÖ

data.text: Can you please define ‚Äûconfident handling on gravel‚Äú? Because the gravel I know is loose, hence nearly no profile will really handle it. Reducing the pressure helps a bit. I use the Almotion from Schwalbe. Fast. Grip enough for travelling üçÄ

data.text: , bigger tires work great for the loose. I have bike with 2, 2.5 and 3‚Äù tires.

I have an Almotion 2.1‚Äù just perfect for my use. Long lasting. And according to feeling and www.bicyclerollingresistance.com : very low resistance

data.text: Btw: very loose ground aka as sand: a 29‚Äù inch wheel trailer works even better ü§ìüòâüòá

data.text: I rode a brand new set of Schwalbe Marathon Plus HS 440s on my fully loaded 100lb bike 3,800 miles from the Pacific Ocean in Oregon to the Atlantic Ocean in Maryland, including the GAP and C&O. I had one flat the entire journey, a goathead thorn in Utah. No complaints and the tires still look practically brand new. Traction was fine everywhere.
data.author: Tony Ionno

data.text: Can,t even remember when i had a flat.
data.author: Mac Ketting

data.text: Schwalbe Mondial DD for touring on a variety of roadbeds.
data.author: Jim Ford

data.text: On my bike I ride Continental Gatorakin and I love them, granted I‚Äôm only on the road but they have never give me a flat ever!! Same tires I used on my bike for the Ironman.
data.author: Jon Redcorn

data.text: We have been using Schwalbe Mondials on our cross country tour and now Europe and the UK.
data.author: Frosene Sacco

data.text: My Schwalbe marathon plus has traveled 15.000 km without any flats and are still going strong. Highly recommended. The marathon plus tour could maybe be an option as well.
